body.p:
Louisville Dec 10th 1861 --
Hon. B. Magoffin.
Gov. State of Ky.
Sir

Sometime in the latter part of Octo. (1861.) last I met a Gentleman by the name of Devenport near the corner of 9th & Main Streets in this City. He said to me he had several letters of introduction from Gentlemen of Bowling Green he wished me to see. We stepped into a coffee House Kept by a Mr Tammage, and took seats in the sitting room room. two other Gentlemen present, whilst in conversation Thomas R. Parrent come in from an adjoining room. Rather intoxicated, evidently excited. The langauge & manner rather insulting. none of the Gentlemen in the room spoke. at length Tammage asked Parrent who he ment by this remarks he said Walker (one of the Gentlemen present) Walker trew down his head, without reply. Parrent continued to talk. When Tammage said to Strange who is very Deaf. "Genl it is you Tom's talking of says are a Damned Secesh." Stange putting his hand to his Ear said. "What." Tammage repeated the words. Strange Jumped up & with a little Hickory stick he had in his hand struck Parrent a smart Blow across the forehead over the left Eye.

Mr Tammage afterward said he was wrong as Parrent had not named Genl Strange. The next Day Strange sent
Dr Devenport to say to Parrent he had struck him under missaprehension & would make any reperaton a Gentleman could. He refusing to except any.
Hence the Presentment & fine of which I request the exercise of the Governors Clemency for relief

Ten dollars is the amount of fine imposed in this case, and considering all the circumstances, known by me, since the trial & of which the petitioner, had not the benefit at the trail of the cause, I respectfully recommend to Your Excellency Genl Strange as a high toned Gentleman, and his cause worthy of Executive clemency.
I unite with Mr Reasor in recommending the case of my friend Genl Strange to your favorable consideration
